quiz.title: Unit 3: Demand and Supply (Quiz 6)
quiz.subtitle: 3.6 Supply Schedules and Curves: Graphical Representation of Supply (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Supply Schedules, Supply Curves, Graphing Supply, Market Supply

questions.question: A supply schedule is:
options: A graph showing the relationship between price and quantity supplied
A table showing the relationship between price and quantity supplied
A list of producer costs for different production levels
A consumer's shopping list at different income levels
questions.explanation: A supply schedule is a table that shows the quantity of a good that producers are willing and able to sell at various prices during a specific time period.

questions.question: On a standard supply curve graph, which variable is plotted on the horizontal axis?
questions.explanation: In economics graphing convention, quantity supplied is always plotted on the horizontal (x) axis and price on the vertical (y) axis.

questions.question: Consider this supply schedule: At $5, quantity supplied is 100 units; at $10, quantity supplied is 300 units. What does this demonstrate?
questions.explanation: This shows the direct relationship between price and quantity supplied - as price increases from $5 to $10, quantity supplied increases from 100 to 300 units, illustrating the law of supply.

questions.question: When plotting a supply curve from a supply schedule, the curve typically:
options: Slopes downward from left to right
Slopes upward from left to right
questions.explanation: Supply curves slope upward from left to right, reflecting the direct relationship between price and quantity supplied - higher prices correspond to higher quantities supplied.

questions.question: A market supply curve is derived by:
options: Taking the highest individual supply at each price
questions.explanation: Market supply is found by summing the quantities supplied by all individual producers at each price point - this is called horizontal summation of individual supply curves.

questions.question: If a supply curve shifts to the right, this indicates:
options: A decrease in supply at every price
An increase in supply at every price
A movement along the supply curve
A change in the good's price
questions.explanation: A rightward shift of the supply curve means that at every price level, producers are willing to supply more quantity than before - this represents an increase in supply.

questions.question: On a supply curve graph, a change in the good's own price causes:
options: A shift of the entire supply curve
A rotation of the supply curve
A change in the curve's slope
questions.explanation: Changes in the good's own price cause movement along the supply curve, while changes in other factors (technology, input costs, etc.) cause shifts of the entire curve.

questions.question: A supply schedule shows: Price $20 - Quantity 500; Price $25 - Quantity 700; Price $30 - Quantity 900. At what price would quantity supplied be 800 units?
questions.explanation: Between $25 (700 units) and $30 (900 units), quantity increases by 200 units for a $5 price increase. To reach 800 units (100 more than 700), price would be $25 + ($5/200 × 100) = $25 + $2.50 = $27.50.

questions.question: If production technology improves, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Improved technology reduces production costs, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: The difference between individual supply and market supply is that:
options: Market supply is the sum of all individual supplies
Market supply only considers large producers
questions.explanation: Market supply represents the total quantity of a good that all producers in the market are willing to sell at each price, obtained by summing individual supply curves horizontally.

questions.question: A perfectly elastic supply curve would appear on a graph as:
questions.explanation: Perfectly elastic supply means producers are willing to supply any quantity at a specific price, represented by a horizontal supply curve.

questions.question: When creating a supply curve from a supply schedule, each point on the curve represents:
questions.explanation: Each point on a supply curve represents a specific price and the corresponding quantity that producers are willing to supply at that price.

questions.question: If the price of inputs (raw materials) increases, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Higher input costs make production more expensive, reducing the quantity producers are willing to supply at each price, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: A supply curve that becomes steeper indicates:
questions.explanation: A steeper supply curve indicates less price elasticity - quantity supplied is less responsive to price changes.

questions.question: On a supply curve graph, the area above the supply curve but below the market price represents:
questions.explanation: Producer surplus is the difference between what producers receive (market price) and the minimum they would accept (shown by the supply curve), represented by the area above the supply curve but below the price.

questions.question: If new firms enter a market, the market supply curve will:
questions.explanation: More producers means more production capacity at each price level, increasing overall market supply and shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: A supply schedule for bicycles shows: $100 - 200 bikes; $150 - 400 bikes; $200 - 600 bikes. What is the quantity supplied at $125?
questions.explanation: Between $100 (200 bikes) and $150 (400 bikes), quantity increases by 200 bikes for a $50 price increase. At $125 ($25 increase from $100), quantity = 200 + (200/50 × 25) = 200 + 100 = 300 bikes.

questions.question: The slope of a supply curve represents:
options: The rate at which quantity supplied changes as price changes
questions.explanation: The slope of the supply curve shows how much quantity supplied changes for each unit change in price, though elasticity provides a better measure of responsiveness.

questions.question: If government regulations increase production costs for manufacturers, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Increased regulations raise production costs, reducing the quantity producers are willing to supply at each price, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: The main purpose of graphing supply schedules is to:
options: Visually represent the price-quantity relationship for producers
questions.explanation: Converting supply schedules into supply curves provides a visual representation of the relationship between price and quantity supplied, making it easier to analyze producer behavior and predict market responses to price changes.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand supply schedules and curves and can interpret graphical representations of supply.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but review how to derive supply curves from schedules and the factors that cause supply shifts.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Supply schedule = price-quantity table; Supply curve = graphical representation; Right shift = supply increase; Left shift = supply decrease.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that supply curves slope upward and show the relationship between price and quantity supplied. Practice converting supply schedules into graphs.
